page.title: 16Ponter's Ball
page.content: Its name is said to be a corruption of "Pontis Vallum", the "wall of the bridge" or neck of land joining the Isle of Avalon to the mainland. It originally ran right across this ridge between tracts of scarcely passable marsh controlling the entry to Glastonbury by land, the ditch being on the east side. It formed both a visible boundary and defence line .It has never been properly excavated and date is uncertain, but it probably dates from the Dark Ages. However, it has been suggested that it might mark the boundary of a pre-Roman religious site covering the Glastonbury area.
